awd_abstract_narration:
Global Riemannian Geometry generalizes the classical Euclidean, Spherical, and Hyperbolic geometries. One of the major challenges in this area of study is to understand how local geometric invariants such as curvature, that is, how the space under consideration "bends",  relate to global topological invariants such as fundamental group, which indicates whether or not the space has 1-dimensional "holes". Manifolds with curvature bounds have been studied intensively since the conception of global Riemannian geometry. One relatively recent approach, which is the focus of this project, to the study of manifolds with lower curvature bounds has been the introduction of symmetries. Graduate students will be trained through research.

The principal investigator will pursue a program in which she carefully studies and analyzes symmetries of both Riemannian manifolds with lower curvature bounds and Alexandrov spaces, considering both sectional curvature and Ricci curvature lower bounds and their corresponding generalizations to Alexandrov spaces, with an eye to gaining a deeper understanding of  this largely unknown class of spaces.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Global Riemannian Geometry generalizes the classical Euclidean, Spherical and Hyberbolic geometries. One of the major challenges is to understand how local invariants such as curvature, which measures how the space "bends",  relate to global topological invariants such as fundamental group, which tells us about the basic shape or "holes" of the space. 

Since the conception of global Riemannian geometry, manifolds with curvature bounds have been studied intensively.  One fruitful approach to studying manifolds with lower curvature bounds has been to introduce symmetries. This approach can also be used to study the more general class of spaces known as Alexandrov spaces.

In this project, the PI analyzed and studied symmetries of both Riemannian manifolds with lower curvature bounds and Alexandrov spaces, considering  sectional curvature, Ricci curvature, and intermediate (p, n)-scalar curvature lower bounds and in the first two cases, their corresponding generalizations to Alexandrov spaces, with an eye to gaining a deeper understanding of  this largely unknown class of spaces. 

 Intellectual Merit:

Two important results from this project are highlighted below.

The first is the classification of closed, simply-connected manifolds of non-negative sectional curvature admitting an isometric almost isotropy-maximal torus action. Zheting Dong, Christine Escher, and the PI showed that these manifolds are products of spheres or the quotients of products spheres by a free torus action. This work extends previous classification results of Escher and the PI for the same class of manifolds admitting an isometric isotropy-maximal torus action.  The isotropy-maximal classification has consequences for the maximal symmetry rank conjecture for non-negatively curved manifolds and led to a classification of closed, simply-connected manifolds of non-negative curvature admitting a torus action of maximal symmetry rank in dimensions less than or equal to 9. The result for almost isotropy-maximal actions should help advance our understanding of closed, simply-connected manifolds of non-negative curvature of almost maximal symmetry rank.

The second result is the classification of closed, simply-connected manifolds of positive sectional curvature admitting an isometric discrete 2-torus action, where a discrete 2-torus is the r-fold product of 2-groups. Elahe Khalili Samani, Lee Kennard, and the PI classify such manifolds in the case where the rank of the discrete 2-torus is maximal, half-maximal, and quarter-maximal, generalizing the corresponding results for a torus action, namely, the Maximal Symmetry Rank theorem due to Karsten Grove and the PI and the Half-Maximal Symmetry Rank theorem due to Burkhard Wilking.

Broader Impacts:

Matthew Burkemper, jointly supervised by the PI and Mark Walsh, completed his PhD thesis at Wichita State University in Spring 2021.  Austin Bosgraaf, completed his masters thesis under the PI's supervision while at Wichita State University in Spring 2020..

The PI is currently supervising the PhD thesis of Farida Ghazawneh and the masters thesis of Samuel Bartel, both at Wichita State University. Farida is expected to complete her degree in 2025, while Samuel is expected to complete his degree in Spring 2024. 

The PI is also co-supervising, with Christine Escher, the PhD thesis of Austin Bosgraaf at Oregon State University, who is expected to complete his degree in 2025.

The PI co-organized a number of seminars and conferences, including five AMS special sessions, three iterations of the Midwest Geometry Conference, held at Iowa State University, Wichita State University, and Kansas State University, respectively, and the Symmetries in Geometry on the Southern Great Plains conference. The PI also participated in a number of outreach activities, including being lead organizer of the first and second Sonia Kovalevsky Day, held in 2022 and 2023, respectively,  speaking at the Wichita State University Math Circle a number of times, participating in the Fairmount Summer Community Outreach program, acting as faculty advisor to the recently created WSU math club, and mentoring students both at WSU and other undergraduate institutions via the Math Alliance F-GAP program.
